node.statement: (Case k=1: Sub-Gaussian exponential moments for linear functionals) Let f in C^inf(T^3) and consider the linear functional phi -> <f, phi> = integral_T^3 f(x) phi(x) dx. By the definition of sub-Gaussian tails (Definition sub_Gaussian_tails), the Phi^4_3 measure mu satisfies: for every continuous linear functional L on D'(T^3), there exists C_L > 0 such that E_mu[exp(alpha L(phi))] <= exp(C_L alpha^2) for all alpha in R. Setting L(phi) = <f, phi>, which is a continuous linear functional on D'(T^3) (since f in C^inf(T^3) subset H^1(T^3) subset the Cameron-Martin space, and <f, phi> extends continuously to phi in H^{-1}(T^3) supset D'(T^3)), we obtain E_mu[exp(alpha <f, phi>)] <= exp(C_f alpha^2) < infinity for all alpha in R, where C_f depends on f through ||f||_{H^1}. This establishes exponential integrability for k=1. Reference: Barashkov-Gubinelli (2021, arXiv:2112.05562), Theorem 1.3, which proves sub-Gaussian concentration for the infinite-volume Phi^4_3 measure. The finite-volume (torus) case follows a fortiori from the same variational techniques.
